repository.name: openpilot
repository.description: openpilot is an open source driver assistance system. openpilot performs the functions of Automated Lane Centering and Adaptive Cruise Control for over 150 supported car makes and models.

pull_requests.title: LongitudinaPlanner: add comment about lateral accel calculation
pull_requests.body: This function assumes no roll and no slip factor, which ignores the non-linearity for speed, however a new lookup table needs to be tuned for this so just add a comment. End result is this function can limit acceleration too much in turns

pull_requests.title: Changes required to build on MacOS 12.3
pull_requests.body:
**Description** 

Recently set up OpenPilot dev environment on MacOS 12.3.  I encountered a few issues with setup:

1. Python < 3.8.13 won't compile with latest Apple clang 
https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv/issues/2143#issuecomment-1072032647

1.  Perhaps a similar issue in route.cc  Unable to compile using std::array.  Switch to QStringList

1.  Homebrew ffmpeg now installs version 5 by default.  Need to pin it to `ffmpeg@4` in the mac setup script.


**Verification**

After making these changes, I was able to build for MacOS 12.3 and run replay / UI locally.  Also pushed to my comma 3 and was able to engage and drive as usual.

pull_requests.title: camera_qcom2: target 40ms acquisition time, use register wizard
pull_requests.body:
Target target 40ms acquisition time (25 fps in register wizard) to leave some slack and timing errors in sync signal from panda

Even though only 2 exposure are used, `FINE_INTEGRATION_TIME3` and `FINE_INTEGRATION_TIME4` are still relavant. If they are not set correctly you will get major artefacts.

pull_requests.title: longitudinal MPC: use reset() function instead of recreating the solver in
pull_requests.body:
When the `reset()` function in the longitudinal MPC is called, it is very slow, since the solver is always recreated.
I added a `reset()` functionality in acados and changed the longitudinal MPC in openpilot to use that.

A quick timing comparison of create and reset can be found here:
https://github.com/acados/acados/blob/03af92839caffc5efb4a920a09620dcd2d7cc155/examples/acados_python/timing_example/reset_timing.py
```
# create_time: min 0.2189 ms mean 0.2586 ms max 0.6881 ms over 10000 executions
# reset_time: min 0.0036 ms mean 0.0047 ms max 0.0906 ms over 10000 executions
```

Most relevant changes in acados:
- Resetting 
- I realized that the NaN reset test in openpilot was still failing after adding a `reset()` function to the acados OCP solver https://github.com/acados/acados/pull/796 , while for the one I had added in acados this reset function was enough
- Resetting also the HPIPM memory (implemented here: https://github.com/acados/acados/pull/803) makes the openpilot NaN reset test pass.

I guess all that is left to do is updating the binaries for Comma 2 and Comma 3 devices.

pull_requests.title: Lock SR within EKF with bool in carParams
pull_requests.body:
SR causes a lot of headaches and personally was never accurate on my vehicle. 
Steering was jerky and cut hard corners very badly or oversteered to the curb. 

Just overriding the value causes it's own issues. namely stiffness factor is not learned effectively. but it's done in  forks because it still performs better in some cases. 

After setting my steering ratio to the stock value Stiffness Factor was re-learned to ~0.665 
I used this value in my interface.py to scale the front/rear stiffness and now have the improved accuracy steering in straights and curves without breaking the learner, so now it can learn stiffness and any others from the dynamic model while locking the SR.

pull_requests.title: enable saving learned steering stiffness only reset on extreme drops in stiffnessFactor.
pull_requests.body:
currently the steering stiffness factor is discarded on every drive to avoid using a value that's extremely low due to rain on a previous drive. 

This change puts a lower limit on how much it can be learned down before the value is reset and allows the stiffness factor to be saved / learned higher.

EKF value should reset when it was previously learned significantly low but possibly not back to one. 
EKF value should not be reset when it was learned "up" 

I do not have the data to back up 
"reset to 0.95 when lower than  0.90" 
but there should be some allowance for learning the tire stiffness down without resetting. 
otherwise this can be if params[sf] < 1.0: params[sf] = 1.0

pull_requests.title: Toyota: cut torque before steering fault
pull_requests.body:
Will need to look at a lot of different cars to verify the numbers, but in a Toyota Camry Hybrid 2022, steering faults when the steering angle rate from the message `STEER_ANGLE_SENSOR` is above 100 degrees/sec for longer than either 21 or 25 cycles/frames.

Not sure what the purpose is of this, but the signal we check for temporary steering faults (`EPS_STATUS->LKA_STATE`) goes to either 25 or 21 on rising edge of a fault, and it seems to describe to the number of sent steering messages where the wheel has been above 100 deg/s. We can also request zero torque and set the torque request bit to 1, and we still fault under the exact same conditions. So the EPS isn't looking at commanded torque, driver torque, or EPS torque at all for faults.

With this change, the user can override as fast as possible and no faults should occur as we cut steering until the rate falls below the threshold the EPS seems to have internally.

We may be able to send messages at a lower rate and then keep steering for longer, as perhaps the internal counter for the rate limit works on messages, not time (as do the torque rate limits).

pull_requests.title: Toyota: use driver torque for torque limits
pull_requests.body:
Just like all the other cars. Chrysler is the only make left, and if that works well with this common method then we can remove EPS torque limiting entirely (from openpilot and panda), as it sometimes limits torque needlessly when the driver isn't touching the wheel at all.

Unclear if this provides much better control or placebo, need to get a route on the same stretch of road and compare.

Might fault without updating panda torque limiting if you try this branch

pull_requests.title: hyundai: better longitudinal control
pull_requests.body:
The following changes improve starting from a stop and make brake control more consistent and lag less:
* when stopped and you want to start moving, make a large accel request until the brakes release
* always tell the vehicle there is a lead 1 meter away

Both of these seem to be required for a consistent, quick start start from stop.  It still takes around a second, but I think it is as fast as stock and no one will complain (any slow movement after you start rolling is the planners fault).

Always telling the vehicle there is a lead 1 meter away seems to make braking way more responsive.  So much that it seems like the lag is only about 0.5 seconds (or less) normally now and we no longer need to add double the error where accel is negative.

This has only been tested on a 2020 palisade and the request values used to get you started when stopped may need to be adjusted for different vehicles (but hopefully not).  I set these values kind of conservative for now because if you set them higher the vehicle does start faster, but it will always go all the way to the requested value and this can cause a harsh jerk when the transition happens back to the plan accel (if it is still small and positive).

I also noticed that sometimes the plan can take a while to reach `vEgoStarting` which caused further delay starting from a stop, so lowering it makes starting from a stop faster and more consistent.  Perhaps we want to do this for other manufacturers, too.

pull_requests.title: controlsState: add override state with grey border
pull_requests.body:
When pre-enabling with gas pressed we change the UI border and alert color to light grey to signify we're not fully enabled (active).

- `State.overriding` can only be entered when engaged or if we're enabling
- `gasPressed` renamed to `gasPressedPreEnable` to match how it affects the state machine.

What it looks like: https://imgur.com/a/zkJYYZc

*This PR adds all code needed for this change, it doesn't change behavior on its own*

pull_requests.title: Simulator Tests in CI
pull_requests.body:
Trying to create carla + bridge.py CI test. Just the start of issue https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/issues/2572
Current test is very basic: First starts Carla, then runs bridge.py. If connection is not made in 50 seconds the test will fail. The simulation and bridge.py will close quitely after 60 seconds.

However, GPU is really needed to run carla so at the moment the tests are failing.

- [x] Cleanup

issues.title: Changes required to build on MacOS 12.3
issues.body:
**Description** 

Recently set up OpenPilot dev environment on MacOS 12.3.  I encountered a few issues with setup:

1. Python < 3.8.13 won't compile with latest Apple clang 
https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv/issues/2143#issuecomment-1072032647

1.  Perhaps a similar issue in route.cc  Unable to compile using std::array.  Switch to QStringList

1.  Homebrew ffmpeg now installs version 5 by default.  Need to pin it to `ffmpeg@4` in the mac setup script.


**Verification**

After making these changes, I was able to build for MacOS 12.3 and run replay / UI locally.  Also pushed to my comma 3 and was able to engage and drive as usual.

issues.title: camera_qcom2: target 40ms acquisition time, use register wizard
issues.body:
Target target 40ms acquisition time (25 fps in register wizard) to leave some slack and timing errors in sync signal from panda

Even though only 2 exposure are used, `FINE_INTEGRATION_TIME3` and `FINE_INTEGRATION_TIME4` are still relavant. If they are not set correctly you will get major artefacts.

issues.title: longitudinal MPC: use reset() function instead of recreating the solver in
issues.body:
When the `reset()` function in the longitudinal MPC is called, it is very slow, since the solver is always recreated.
I added a `reset()` functionality in acados and changed the longitudinal MPC in openpilot to use that.

A quick timing comparison of create and reset can be found here:
https://github.com/acados/acados/blob/03af92839caffc5efb4a920a09620dcd2d7cc155/examples/acados_python/timing_example/reset_timing.py
```
# create_time: min 0.2189 ms mean 0.2586 ms max 0.6881 ms over 10000 executions
# reset_time: min 0.0036 ms mean 0.0047 ms max 0.0906 ms over 10000 executions
```

Most relevant changes in acados:
- Resetting 
- I realized that the NaN reset test in openpilot was still failing after adding a `reset()` function to the acados OCP solver https://github.com/acados/acados/pull/796 , while for the one I had added in acados this reset function was enough
- Resetting also the HPIPM memory (implemented here: https://github.com/acados/acados/pull/803) makes the openpilot NaN reset test pass.

I guess all that is left to do is updating the binaries for Comma 2 and Comma 3 devices.

issues.title: honda: acceleration oscillations after reaching target speed
issues.body:
### Describe the bug

Bug can be reproduced/observed on mostly flat roads. 
The humans in the car feel minor acceleration oscillations which coincide with the tachometer going slightly up and down.
One interesting observation is that when it does happen, comma 3 shows an actual speed of 1 mph lower than car's (e.g. car shows 64 but openpilot shows 65). 

It feels like a classic PID controller oscillation.



### What hardware does this issue affect?

comma three

### Which car does this affect?

Honda Odyssey 2019

### Provide a route where the issue occurs

0c23034a3a1e7bf4|2022-03-29--12-23-57--0

### openpilot version

0.8.13

### Additional info

_No response_

issues.title: verify new car ports and fingerprints
UI: body support
Make sure actuatorsOutput is accurate
issues.body: For example, some Hyundai longitudinal actuator values aren't accurate as they're finalized in hyundaican: https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/blob/master/selfdrive/car/hyundai/hyundaican.py#L100

issues.title: controls: transition into full stopAccel if already at a standstill
Lock SR within EKF with bool in carParams
issues.body:
SR causes a lot of headaches and personally was never accurate on my vehicle. 
Steering was jerky and cut hard corners very badly or oversteered to the curb. 

Just overriding the value causes it's own issues. namely stiffness factor is not learned effectively. but it's done in  forks because it still performs better in some cases. 

After setting my steering ratio to the stock value Stiffness Factor was re-learned to ~0.665 
I used this value in my interface.py to scale the front/rear stiffness and now have the improved accuracy steering in straights and curves without breaking the learner, so now it can learn stiffness and any others from the dynamic model while locking the SR.

issues.title: enable saving learned steering stiffness only reset on extreme drops in stiffnessFactor.
issues.body:
currently the steering stiffness factor is discarded on every drive to avoid using a value that's extremely low due to rain on a previous drive. 

This change puts a lower limit on how much it can be learned down before the value is reset and allows the stiffness factor to be saved / learned higher.

EKF value should reset when it was previously learned significantly low but possibly not back to one. 
EKF value should not be reset when it was learned "up" 

I do not have the data to back up 
"reset to 0.95 when lower than  0.90" 
but there should be some allowance for learning the tire stiffness down without resetting. 
otherwise this can be if params[sf] < 1.0: params[sf] = 1.0

issues.title: Toyota: cut torque before steering fault
issues.body:
Will need to look at a lot of different cars to verify the numbers, but in a Toyota Camry Hybrid 2022, steering faults when the steering angle rate from the message `STEER_ANGLE_SENSOR` is above 100 degrees/sec for longer than either 21 or 25 cycles/frames.

Not sure what the purpose is of this, but the signal we check for temporary steering faults (`EPS_STATUS->LKA_STATE`) goes to either 25 or 21 on rising edge of a fault, and it seems to describe to the number of sent steering messages where the wheel has been above 100 deg/s. We can also request zero torque and set the torque request bit to 1, and we still fault under the exact same conditions. So the EPS isn't looking at commanded torque, driver torque, or EPS torque at all for faults.

With this change, the user can override as fast as possible and no faults should occur as we cut steering until the rate falls below the threshold the EPS seems to have internally.

We may be able to send messages at a lower rate and then keep steering for longer, as perhaps the internal counter for the rate limit works on messages, not time (as do the torque rate limits).

issues.title: Improve alert verbosity
issues.body:
Alerts should give more insight into what the actual problem is.

- [ ] Camera Malfunction might also be lag. Remove "contact support", show which camera(s) are lagging, and ensure it's not showing when the whole system is lagging.
- [ ] commIssue should show the processes that are lagging 
- [x] startupNoFw: can we make more clear that the ob-ii port is used for fingerprinting
- [ ] outOfSpace: almost never happens, but show remaining space?
- [ ]  overheat: show temperature
- [ ] calibrationInvalid: show angles
- [ ] processNotRunning: show process name
- [ ] modeldLagging: show frame drop percentage 
- [ ] lowMemory: show remaining memory 
- [ ] highCpuUsage: show cpu usage (unused I think) 
- [ ] canError: show bus(es) for whole dropout, message id(s) for wrong checksum/counter
- [ ] relayMalfunction: explain actual fault?
- [ ] Model Output Uncertain: posenet speed vs car speed

issues.title: Toyota: use driver torque for torque limits
issues.body:
Just like all the other cars. Chrysler is the only make left, and if that works well with this common method then we can remove EPS torque limiting entirely (from openpilot and panda), as it sometimes limits torque needlessly when the driver isn't touching the wheel at all.

Unclear if this provides much better control or placebo, need to get a route on the same stretch of road and compare.

Might fault without updating panda torque limiting if you try this branch

issues.title: hyundai: better longitudinal control
issues.body:
The following changes improve starting from a stop and make brake control more consistent and lag less:
* when stopped and you want to start moving, make a large accel request until the brakes release
* always tell the vehicle there is a lead 1 meter away

Both of these seem to be required for a consistent, quick start start from stop.  It still takes around a second, but I think it is as fast as stock and no one will complain (any slow movement after you start rolling is the planners fault).

Always telling the vehicle there is a lead 1 meter away seems to make braking way more responsive.  So much that it seems like the lag is only about 0.5 seconds (or less) normally now and we no longer need to add double the error where accel is negative.

This has only been tested on a 2020 palisade and the request values used to get you started when stopped may need to be adjusted for different vehicles (but hopefully not).  I set these values kind of conservative for now because if you set them higher the vehicle does start faster, but it will always go all the way to the requested value and this can cause a harsh jerk when the transition happens back to the plan accel (if it is still small and positive).

I also noticed that sometimes the plan can take a while to reach `vEgoStarting` which caused further delay starting from a stop, so lowering it makes starting from a stop faster and more consistent.  Perhaps we want to do this for other manufacturers, too.

issues.title: modeld cannot recover when bridge is terminated

labels.name: PC
labels.description: Issues related to running openpilot on PC

issues.body:
### Describe the bug

When bridge.py is terminated, it seems that modeld should keep trying until a frame is received. (https://github.com/commaai/openpilot/blob/master/selfdrive/modeld/modeld.cc#L89)
However modeld stucks in printing `vipc_client_main no frame` error messages even after bridge.py is restarted. 


### OS Version

Ubuntu 18.04

### openpilot version or commit

_No response_

### Additional info

_No response_

issues.title: PlotJuggler: better support Cabana links
issues.body: Currently if you click "Copy Share Link" and try to use PJ, you get authentication errors which aren't solved by authenticating (due to the sig field). This also fixes not detecting routes without logs, where it previously just loaded up an empty PJ screen without asking to load qlogs. And you now can copy the Cabana link directly from your address bar
